Echidna.food: insects such as ants and termites, beetle larvae and worms
Echidna.description: Echidnas, also called spiny anteaters, are walking contradictions. They are mammals, but they lay eggs. They have fleshy noses instead of beaks, and their bodies are covered in hollow, barbless quills.

Tasmanian Devil.food: meat from animals such as wallabies and wombats
Tasmanian Devil.description: The Tasmanian devil is a carnivorous marsupial. About the size of a small dog, it became the largest carnivorous marsupial after the thylacine's extinction in 1936.

Quokka.food: plants such as shrubs and grasses
Quokka.description: The quokka resembles other wallabies and was first described as a rat-sized cat. It has coarse grey-brown fur and a short, mostly hairless tail.
Quokka.found: Rottnest Island and parts of Western Australia

Frill-necked Lizard.description: When threatened, this lizard rises on its hind legs, opens its yellow mouth, unfurls its colorful frill, and hisses. If that fails, it runs to the nearest tree.

Hawksbill Turtle.food: animals like sponges and jellyfish, and sea plants
Hawksbill Turtle.description: The Hawksbill Turtle has a bird-like beak and a shell with overlapping scutes and serrated edges. Females average 50kg and have an 80cm shell.
Hawksbill Turtle.found: Tropical coasts of Queensland, Northern Territory, and Western Australia

Perentie.food: carnivorous, eats animals like kangaroos, rabbits, lizards, and birds
Perentie.description: The Perentie is Australia's largest monitor lizard. It is shy and lives in remote deserts. It held cultural significance for Aboriginal people.

Cassowary.food: plant matter like fruit, insects, and small animals
Cassowary.description: Cassowaries are large, flightless birds with powerful legs and a prehistoric appearance. Though shy, they can be dangerous when provoked.

Kookaburra.food: insects and small animals including snakes, frogs, and lizards
Kookaburra.description: The laughing kookaburra is the largest member of the kingfisher family, known for its distinctive call that sounds like laughter.

Yellow Tailed Black Cockatoo.food: fruit, seeds, and other plant material
Yellow Tailed Black Cockatoo.description: These cockatoos have dark feathers with yellow markings. They fly slowly with a wailing call and are found in temperate forests of southeastern Australia.
